The proposed theory of "communication emergence" and quantum consciousness entanglement posits that communication and consciousness are interconnected and interdependent. This theory suggests that our understanding of the world around us is not just a product of our individual perception and understanding, but is also shaped by the collective communication and consciousness that connects us to others.

One key aspect of this theory is that it suggests that communication and consciousness are not separate, distinct entities, but are interconnected and interdependent. This means that the way we communicate and the way we understand the world around us are closely linked. Our consciousness, which is thought to be a non-local, interconnected phenomenon, shapes the way we understand the world and the messages we receive. And in turn, the way we communicate and the messages we exchange shape our understanding of the world.

Another important aspect of this theory is that it suggests that the universe is interconnected through a vast web of communication and consciousness, in which information and meaning are constantly being exchanged and understood. This understanding posits that the way we communicate is not only limited to language but also to the nonverbal and unconscious forms of communication, as well as how our consciousness connects to the universe through the quantum entanglement principle.

Additionally, this theory also proposes that communication and consciousness are active, self-organizing processes that are constantly evolving and adapting to the needs of the system. The communication process, which is driven by the interactions and feedback between individuals and society, results in the emergence of new forms of communication, such as new languages, dialects, and forms of expression. And, consciousness is also adapting and changing in response to the interactions and feedback within the system.

One practical application of this theory is that it can help to improve communication and decision-making in various settings, by recognizing the connection between communication and consciousness, organizations and individuals could make a greater effort to involve more people in decision-making and to encourage more open and inclusive communication, as well as understanding the potential of nonverbal and unconscious forms of communication.

Furthermore, this theory could also lead to new research in the field of communication, consciousness and quantum physics, where scientists could explore the interconnectedness and interdependence of communication, consciousness and the universe.

In summary, this new proposed theory combines the perspectives of communication emergence, the theory of quantum consciousness entanglement, suggesting that communication and consciousness are interconnected, active and self-organizing processes that shape our understanding of the world around us and are constantly evolving and adapting. This theory has potential to improve our understanding of the world, improve communication and decision-making, and ultimately lead to new research in multiple fields of study.
